content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is given a solution of phenol red of unknown concentration. Solutions of phenol red are bright pink under basic conditions. A. The student uses a <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> probe and determines that the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the solution is <math alttext="11.20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the hydrogen ion concentration, <math alttext="the molar concentration of H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></math>, in the solution of phenol red.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is given a solution of phenol red of unknown concentration. Solutions of phenol red are bright pink under basic conditions. A. The student uses a <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> probe and determines that the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the solution is <math alttext="11.20" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the hydrogen ion concentration, <math alttext="the molar concentration of H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></math>, in the solution of phenol red.

The student analyzes a sample of the solution using a spectrophotometer set at a wavelength of <math alttext="559 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>559</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the wavelength of maximum absorbance for phenol red. The measured absorbance of the phenol red solution at <math alttext="559 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>559</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. B. Based on the calibration curve shown below, what is the concentration of the solution in micromoles per liter <math alttext="micromolar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>Î¼</mi><mi>M</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

C. If the student mixed <math alttext="10 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of distilled water with <math alttext="10 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the sample, would this diluted solution have an absorbance greater than, less than, or equal to the absorbance of the original solution? Justify your answer.

D. If the student measured the absorbance of the solution at a wavelength of <math alttext="650 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>650</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, would the absorbance be greater than, less than, or equal to the absorbance of the solution at <math alttext="559 nanometers " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>559</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.
